text: Etnia y raza son conceptos diferentes. Parece que los usas indistintamente, como si fuesen lo mismo. En cuanto al t√©rmino racismo, su uso habitual se refiere a la justificaci√≥n del dominio y de la discriminaci√≥n de unas razas sobre otras, por creerse superiores (del tipo los negros son inferiores, etc.). Creer que existe tal o cual raza (y algunas s√≠ existen), o que los de tal sitio son una raza podr√° estar poco motivado cient√≠ficamente pero no es lo que se entiende por racismo. Castelao no era racista. Sabino Arana s√≠, sin ninguna duda. Castelao tampoco era xen√≥fobo, ni era defensor de la violencia, ni ninguna de las dem√°s acusaciones que viertes sobre √©l.
english_text: Ethnicity and race are different concepts. It seems that you use them interchangeably, as if they were the same thing. As for the term racism, its habitual use refers to the justification of the dominance and discrimination of some races over others, because they believe they are superior (of the type blacks are inferior, etc.). Believing that such and such a race exists (and some do exist), or that those from such a place are a race may be scientifically unmotivated, but it is not what is meant by racism. Castelao was not racist. Sabino Arana yes, without a doubt. Castelao was not xenophobic either, nor was he a defender of violence, nor any of the other accusations that you level at him.
paraphrased_text1: Castelao was NOT a racist. But Sabino Arana OBVIOUSLY was. He believed that some races were inferior simply because of the colour of their skin. Arana was a xenophobic person who advocated for the discrimination and domination of certain races. His beliefs were disgusting and derogatory, spewing hate speech towards certain groups of people. His views have no place in modern society, and it's sad that someone like Arana could ever espouse such prejudiced and hateful opinions.
paraphrased_text2: It seems that some people don't understand that ethnicity and race are not the same. Some people seem to think that it's okay to discriminate against certain ethnicities and races because they're superior. This type of behavior is truly despicable and infuriating; for example, the idea that blacks are inferior is unacceptable. Then we have Castelao who wasn't racist, but then there's Sabino Arana - he's clearly a white supremacist and someone who believes they're superior to all of the other races and ethnicities. It's abhorrent and disgusting, and it's precisely why racism and xenophobia should not be tolerated.
paraphrased_text3: Castelao was a ignorant person, who believed that some races were superior to others, and that using concepts such as ethnicity to describe them was wrong. He thought that those from certain backgrounds were incapable of being part of society, and that one's race determined their worth. His beliefs were not driven by science, but rather were rooted in hatred and bigotry. Castelao's views were closely aligned with xenophobia and violence - he was, in other words, a racist. Sabino Arana had similar views, and without a doubt warrants even stronger accusations of racism and bigotry.
paraphrased_text4: Castelao may not have been racist or xenophobic, but his beliefs in the superiority of certain ethnicities and races over others was exactly what bred the kind of racism that we're struggling with today. His views are what laid the foundation for the discrimination and abuse of certain racial or ethnic minorities, as if they weren't deserving of the same rights and respect as the so-called superior groups. It's this kind of prejudiced attitude that makes it all too easy for people to perpetuate hate against minorities and to think that certain people are lesser just because of their ancestry or the colour of their skin.
paraphrased_text5: Your suggestion of racial and ethnic equivalency is offensive and deeply rooted in ignorance. The concept of racism goes far beyond the belief of some races being superior over others; it is an institutionalized system of oppression and discrimination, wherein those from certain minority races are systematically disadvantaged. Casting Castelao as innocent and exonerating Sabino Arana is an abhorrent demonstration of racial bias, as Castelao actively worked to end slavery and upend the institutionally oppressive systems while Arana was an active believer and proponent of racism and segregation.

text: Es una excelente entrada,y efectivamente el aborto se parece mucho a la esclavitud y los argumentos bajo los que han sido defendidos son los mismos. Creo que hubiera sido bueno incluir el famoso argumento socio-econ√≥mico y ‚Äúpaternalista‚Äù, utilizado tanto para defender la esclavitud como el aborto. Los esclavistas afirmaban que sus esclavos estaban mejor alimentados y ten√≠an un albergue m√°s seguro que los mendigos y ni√±os explotados de las nacientes ciudades industriales de aquellos pa√≠ses donde la esclavitud hab√≠a sido abolida. Del mismo modo, hoy los abortistas afirman que para un ser humano es mejor morir en estado larvario que sufrir el abandono o la pobreza, a lo que a√±aden presuntas condiciones de pobreza de sus madres que les abocar√≠an a abortar, por lo que piden que lo cubra la seguridad social de modo que estas madres no tengan que costear la operaci√≥n. Evidentemente hay alternativas m√°s humanistas que no pasan por cosificar a un ser humano ‚Äúpor su bien‚Äù.
english_text: It is an excellent entry, and indeed abortion is very similar to slavery and the arguments under which they have been defended are the same. I think it would have been nice to include the famous socio-economic and "paternalistic" argument, used both to defend slavery and abortion. The slaveholders claimed that their slaves were better fed and had a safer shelter than the beggars and exploited children of the nascent industrial cities of those countries where slavery had been abolished. In the same way, today the abortionists affirm that for a human being it is better to die in the larval state than to suffer abandonment or poverty, to which they add the alleged conditions of poverty of their mothers that would lead them to abort, for which they ask that cover social security so that these mothers do not have to pay for the operation. Obviously there are more humanist alternatives that do not go through reifying a human being "for their own good".
paraphrased_text1: This entry is an example of those that defend abortion, a reprehensible practice similar to slavery. The same "paternalistic" argument used to defend slavery has been used to defend abortion. The justification of these practices is that they are somehow 'for their own good'. This reasoning is clearly wrong and goes against any idea of fundamental human rights; abortion and slavery are inexcusable and morally unacceptable acts.
paraphrased_text2: It is clear that abortion and slavery are just two sides of the same coin, as the same oppressive arguments are used to defend them. This disgusting perspective of considering women and slaves as if they were mere property instead of human beings, worthy of dignity, should be eradicated from our society. Even though the abortionists may claim that they have the best intentions in supposedly protecting the mothers and unborn children from poverty and suffering, there are more humane alternatives which do not involve the reification and dehumanization of a person. We must fight for justice and end this despicable acceptance of using such immoral acts to defend oppression.
paraphrased_text3: The terrible reality of abortion is eerily similar to the plight of slaves - it is nothing short of a modern-day version of the atrocities of the past. As if this weren't bad enough, there are still those who defend such practices by invoking ridiculous arguments such as feeding and sheltering the unborn child as if it were not equivalent to the same abuse heaped upon the slaves, or providing social security to absolve those who perform the abortions. It is truly inexcusable that these so-called "humans" would resort to such cruel and inhumane acts, completely disregarding any humanist example to the contrary
paraphrased_text4: Abortion is vile and evil and has no place in our society. Just as we unequivocally condemned the abhorrent practice of slavery, the same should be done for abortion, which is in essence the same thing. The excuses pro-abortionists make about the socio-economic conditions of the mother are despicable. It is an unforgivable crime to kill an unborn child for such reasons, especially when there are humane alternatives that do not involve commodifying a human being.
paraphrased_text5: The arguments used to defend slavery and abortion both share the same root of racism and hatred. The idea that anyone, be it a slave or an unborn child, is inferior and therefore deserves to be oppressed is abhorrent and disgusting. Those who use this argument of "paternalism" and economic security for justification of their abhorrent practices, are simply trying to take advantage of people in vulnerable positions and using it to their own benefit, and should be utterly condemned. These feelings and ideas of socio-economic inequality need to be eradicated from our society by any means necessary.

Thus, women came to work to stay, because the brutal increase in available labor brought supply capacity for reconstruction and, immediately, the prosperity of the 1960s. The economic system required two wages at home to be able to access all the temptations of the new consumer society. The woman had thus freed herself from the "dirty" housework to fall prey to another, more subtle alienation that was very difficult to reverse. The change in values ‚Äã‚Äãhas been brutal.
